tn.text: Here "quiet" refers to "peace." AT: "to have peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: than a house full of feasting with strife
tn.text: There are words missing here; "to have" or "to be in" may be added. AT: "than to be in a house full of feasting where there is strife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: The crucible is for silver and the furnace is for gold
tn.text: This refers to how gold and silver are refined. A metal is refined by heating it to a high temperature so that it melts and the impurities may be removed. AT: "The crucible is used to refine silver and the furnace is used to refine gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a pot in which metals are melted at a very high temperature

This speaks of Yahweh testing people to help them stop being evil and foolish as if their hearts were a metal that Yahweh was refining to remove everything that is impure. AT: "Yahweh tests peoples' hearts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here people are referred to by their hearts to emphasize their thoughts and desires. AT: "people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "lips" can be translated as either 1) a synecdoche for the person or 2) a metonym for the words that come out from those lips. AT:  "a wicked person" or "wicked talk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"listens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "tongue" can be translated as either 1) a synecdoche for the person or 2) a metonym for the words that the tongue produces. AT: "a destructive person" or "destructive talk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to poor people. AT: "those who are poor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This is a name that refers to Yahweh. This is also an abstract noun that can be written as a verb. AT: "the one who made him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to the misfortune of others. AT: "at others' misfortune" or "at other peoples' troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This speaks of older peoples' grandchildren being a sign of honor for them as if their grandchildren were a crown. AT: "bring honor and respect to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to older people. AT: "those who are older" or "older people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"Fine speech" or "Excellent speech"

tn.ref: much less are lying lips suitable for royalty
tn.text: This describes people lying as if it were actually their "lips" that were lying. AT: "even more it is not suitable for royalty to lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: A bribe is like a magic stone to the one who gives it
tn.text: This speaks of a person's bribe working by comparing it to a magical stone or amulet. AT: "A bribe works like a magical stone for the one who gives it" or "A bribe works like magic for the one who is giving the bribe" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Here "turning" refers to the various things the person does. Specifically, this refers to the different things the person does by bribery. AT: "in whatever he does" or "in everything he tries to do by giving bribes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
something that hurts or angers a person
This refers to bringing up a past situation in which a friend was hurt or offended. AT: "who repeats a past offense" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"separates"

tn.ref: A rebuke goes deeper into a person ... than a hundred blows go into a fool
tn.text: This compares how a rebuke effects a man of understanding to how a beating effects a fool. This speaks of the effect on these people as if it could be measured by the depth that it goes into them. AT: "A rebuke has more effect on a person ... than a hundred blows have on a fool" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"a person who has good judgment" The word "understand" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "a person who understands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"a beating of a hundred blows goes"
The word "rebellion" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "seeks to rebel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: a cruel messenger will be sent against him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "a cruel messenger will come against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
To be "sent against" someone means to be sent to harm them. AT: "will be sent to harm him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: a bear robbed of her cubs
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "a bear who has just lost her cubs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "foolishness" can be expressed as an adjective. AT: "who is acting foolish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: evil will never leave his house
tn.text: Here "evil" is spoken of as if it were a person who would not leave the man's house. Here the word "house" may be taken literally, but it is also a metonym for his family. AT: "bad things will continue to happen to him and his family" or "bad things will never stop happening to him and his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The beginning of conflict is like one who releases water everywhere
tn.text: This compares how easily a conflict spreads to how spilled water flows everywhere. AT: "Starting a conflict is like pumping water and letting it run everywhere" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"starts"or "begins"

tn.ref: The person who acquits the wicked person and the person who condemns the righteous person
tn.text: "The one who acquits wicked people and the one who condemns the righteous"
justifies, declares someone not guilty

tn.ref: Why should a fool pay money to learn about wisdom, when he has no ability to learn it?
tn.text: This rhetorical question emphasizes that the fool should not do this. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "A fool should not pay money to learn about wisdom because he does not have the ability to learn it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: a brother is born for times of trouble
tn.text: One of the purposes of a brother is to be there to help his brother or sister in times of trouble. AT: "a brother is there for times of trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"no good judgement" (UDB)
This refers to promises that must be kept and are often a burden on the person who made them.

This means that someone will trip on the threshold and break bones, probably in their foot. AT: "is sure to cause someone trip and break their the bones in their foot" or "is sure to cause someone to trip and injure himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The "heart" represents a person's feelings, attitudes and motivations. AT: "who is deceptive" or "who is dishonest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The "tongue" represents a person's speech. AT: "speaks perversely" or "speaks wickedly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"falls into trouble" To "fall into" something means to get into that situation. AT: "will have calamity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: A cheerful heart is good medicine
tn.text: This speaks of a cheerful heart as being good medicine because it makes you feel better. AT: "A cheerful heart is like medicine that makes you feel better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The "heart" represents a person's feelings, attitudes and motivations. AT: "Being cheerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the "spirit" represents a person's feelings and emotional state. A broken spirit refers to a poor emotional state. AT: "depression" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

A person's bones represent their physical health and strength. If a person's bones dry up it means that they are very sick and unhealthy. AT: "makes a person unhealthy and weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to pervert the ways of justice
tn.text: "to prevent justice from being rendered" or "to pervert justice"
This speaks of a person's focus on acting wisely as if he were looking at wisdom. AT: "focuses on acting wisely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the eyes of a fool are
tn.text: This refers to a fool by his eyes to emphasize what he is focusing on. AT: "the fool is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This speaks of a fool's impossible dreams as if they were the ends of the earth to emphasize that they are unrealistic. AT: "strive for things that are as far from him as the ends of the earth" or "focus on impossible things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: A foolish son is a grief to his father
tn.text: This speaks of a son causing his father grief as if the son himself were "grief." AT: "A foolish son brings grief to his father"

tn.ref: A foolish son ... and bitterness to the woman
tn.text: This speaks of a son causing his mother bitterness as if the son himself were "bitterness." AT: "A foolish son ... and brings bitterness to the woman"
"who gave birth to him"
emotional pain, sorrow

tn.ref: it is never good ... neither is it good
tn.text: These statements can be written in positive form. AT: "it is always wrong ... and it is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Another possible meaning is "the innocent person," anyone whom others have accused of a crime that he did not commit.
whip severely
The word "integrity" can be expressed with the adjective "honest." AT: "who are honest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to the way he speaks. AT: "speaks with few words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Even a fool is thought to be wise
tn.text: This can be written in active form. AT: "People even think a fool is wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that he does not speak. AT: "does not speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he is considered to be intelligent
tn.text: This can be written in active form. AT: "people consider him to be intelligent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
